reviews.text: Used this tube station the other day while traveling on business. No complaints, would use again.

This place is ok, because it has some trendy outlet stores in the station, but the station is quite dirty. Fortunately, I met a street artist to better my journey. Trains come every 2 to 3 minutes and there are about four entrances from the subway to Old Street station. I had to get the bus to my next location.

A deep underground station on the Northern line with a mesmerising ceiling.

I was so perplexed that I froze for many hours and upon regaining my senses discovered a pool of coins beside my feet.
The metro and station are hot and dirty. Not very impressed. At least there was a Stranger things poster.

The London Underground is a public rapid transit system in the United Kingdom that serves a large part of Greater London and the home counties of Essex, Hertfordshire and Buckinghamshire. It has many former stations, while others were planned but never formally opened for public use. Some stations were closed down due to low levels of passengers usage rendering them uneconomical; some became redundant after lines were re-routed or replacements were constructed; and others are no longer served by the Underground but remain open to National Rail main line services. Many stations were planned as parts of new lines or extensions to existing ones but were later abandoned.
